3.original_verse: Brahman is the highest imperishable; the highest self is said to be one’s own nature, giving rise to all states of being; action is understood as ‘sending forth’.
3.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: Krishna describes Brahman as the imperishable, the self as one’s nature, and action as the source of all creations.

4.original_verse: Among the embodied, the highest being is finite existence; the highest god is the great spirit; I am the highest sacrifice here in this body, Chosen One.
4.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: Krishna describes Himself as the ultimate sacrifice within the body, encompassing all physical and divine aspects.

5.original_verse: And at the end time, remembering me, freed from the body, the one who departs goes to my state of being. There is no doubt in this matter.
5.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: At the time of death, one who remembers Krishna achieves liberation and enters His state of being.

6.original_verse: Whatever state of being one remembers, when, at the end, one abandons the body, one goes to that state – always changed into that state of being, Son of Kunti.
6.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: The state of mind at the time of death determines the next state of being, emphasizing the power of one's final thoughts.

7.original_verse: For this reason, remember me at all times, and fight with insight and mind placed on me. And doubtless, you will come to me.
7.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: Krishna advises constant remembrance of Him, even during life's duties, as the path to attaining Him.

8.original_verse: With thought joined to the practice of yoga, by turning towards nothing else, one goes to the highest divine spirit, meditating [on that], Son of Pritha.
8.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: Through unwavering focus and yoga, one attains the supreme divine spirit.

9.original_verse: One should meditate on the ancient one, the poet and ruler, smaller than the atom, the supporter of all, whose shape is unknowable, and whose colour is the sun, beyond the dark.
9.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: Krishna instructs meditation on His eternal, subtle, and incomprehensible form as the source of all existence.

10.original_verse: At the time of departure, with a motionless mind, joined to devotion through the strength of yoga, after making the breath enter between the two eyebrows, one goes to this divine, highest spirit.
10.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: Through controlled breath and focused devotion, one unites with the highest spirit.

11.original_verse: I will tell you the path which ascetics enter, without passion, where they follow a celibate vow, and desire that which those who know the Veda call the infinite.
11.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: The ascetic path leads to liberation through detachment and desire for the infinite.

12.original_verse: When one has restricted all the doors [of the body], and kept closed the mind in the heart, and put the breath in the head, abiding in the concentration of yoga.
12.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: Yoga requires control of bodily senses, mind, and breath for supreme concentration.

13.original_verse: When one has said ‘Om’, the Brahman of one syllable, meditating on me, one goes forth, abandons the body, and then travels the highest way.
13.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: Chanting Om and meditating on Krishna leads to the ultimate path of liberation.

14.original_verse: Son of Pritha, for the one whose thought does not ever go elsewhere, who eternally remembers me, for one who practises yoga always joined [to practice], I am easy to find.
14.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: Constant remembrance and devotion make Krishna attainable for devoted yogis.

15.original_verse: When they come near to me, those great selves who have gone to the highest fulfilment do not reach another birth – that impermanent place of sorrow.
15.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: Reaching Krishna liberates souls from rebirth and the impermanent cycle of suffering.

16.original_verse: The worlds are always returning again to birth, up to the world of Brahman. But when one has come near to me, one does not find another rebirth, Son of Kunti.
16.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: Even the highest worlds, including that of Brahma, are impermanent. However, attaining Krishna leads to liberation from the cycle of rebirth.

17.original_verse: The ones who know that a day of Brahma ends at a thousand yugas, and that his night ends at a thousand yugas, are the ones who know the day and the night.
17.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: Brahma's day and night span vast cosmic cycles of creation and dissolution, understood by the wise.

18.original_verse: At the coming of day, all those things which have form come from that which is formless; at the coming of night, they are dissolved at random into that which is known as the formless.
18.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: Creation arises from the unmanifest during Brahma's day, and dissolves back during his night.

19.original_verse: The great group of beings is born again and again, and dissolved at the coming of night; it comes into being again at the coming of day, Son of Pritha.
19.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: The cycle of repeated births and dissolutions continues endlessly during Brahma's cosmic days and nights.

20.original_verse: But higher than this is another state of being which is also formless; it is higher than that formless state existent from the beginning. And when all beings are lost, it does not die.
20.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: Beyond the manifest and unmanifest lies the eternal, imperishable state of the Supreme Being.

21.original_verse: It is said that the imperishable is unseen; they call that the highest way. When they reach this, they do not return. That is my highest abode.
21.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: The imperishable, unseen Supreme Reality is Krishna's highest abode, and those who reach it do not return to the cycle of birth.

22.original_verse: Son of Pritha, this highest being is reachable by singular devotion; all beings stand within it, this whole world is woven through it.
22.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: Through unwavering devotion, one can attain the Supreme Being, who pervades and sustains all existence.

23.original_verse: Bull of the Bharatas, I will tell you the time when those who practise yoga depart, and the time of their returning, and not returning.
23.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: Krishna explains the paths of light and darkness, through which yogis either transcend rebirth or return to it.

24.original_verse: In light, fire and day, or the waxing moon of the month, and the six months of the sun’s northern path, then at that time the ones who know Brahman go to Brahman.
24.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: Yogis who follow the path of light and auspicious times attain Brahman and do not return to rebirth.

25.original_verse: In night and smoke, and the darkening moon of the month, and the six months of the sun’s southern path, then reaching lunar light, the one who practises yoga comes back.
25.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: Yogis on the path of darkness and inauspicious times enjoy lunar worlds but return to rebirth.

26.original_verse: These two ways of light and dark are thought to be eternal for the world; by the first, one does not come back; by the other, one comes back again.
26.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: The eternal paths of light and darkness lead to liberation or rebirth, respectively.

27.original_verse: Son of Pritha, knowing these two paths, the one who practises yoga is not at all confused; because of this, Arjuna, at all times be joined to yoga.
27.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: Awareness of the two paths enables yogis to remain steadfast in their spiritual practice without confusion.

28.original_verse: Knowing all this, one who practises yoga moves beyond the pure fruit fixed in the Vedas, in sacrifices, in gifts and in heated discipline; he goes to the ancient highest place.
28.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: Through yoga, one transcends the rituals and rewards of the Vedas to attain the eternal Supreme State.

1.original_verse: But this most hidden secret I will tell you – as you are the one who does not sneer: knowledge, joined with wisdom – once you’ve learned this, you will be freed from impurity.
1.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: Krishna emphasizes the profound and liberating nature of this knowledge, accessible only to those free from malice.

2.original_verse: It is a kingly knowledge, a kingly secret, a purifier above all, promoting dharma, learned right before your eyes, undying, and pleasant to perform.
2.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: This supreme knowledge, noble and purifying, supports dharma and is easily attainable while being eternal.

3.original_verse: Scorcher of the Enemy, people who do not have trust in this dharma have not reached me; they are born again in the way of death and rebirth.
3.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: Lack of trust in this supreme knowledge leads to repeated cycles of birth and death.

4.original_verse: This whole world is woven through with me, in a shape which is formless; all beings dwell in me, while I do not dwell in them.
4.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: Krishna explains His omnipresence, sustaining all beings while remaining detached and formless.

5.original_verse: Yet neither do beings dwell in me. Behold, my powerful yoga: bearing beings, and yet not dwelling in beings, my own self causing them to be.
5.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: Through divine power, Krishna supports all beings without being confined by them, demonstrating His transcendent nature.

6.original_verse: As a great wind, moving in all places, dwells eternally in the sky, so all beings dwell in me. Think of this.
6.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: Like the wind in the vast sky, all beings exist in Krishna without affecting His essence.

7.original_verse: Son of Kunti, all beings move into my own substance at the burning end of a cycle of ages. And at the birth of an age, I again send them out.
7.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: Krishna cyclically absorbs and manifests all beings, reflecting the eternal cosmic rhythm.

8.original_verse: Borne up by my own material nature, again and again I send out, by the power of material nature, this whole collection of beings which is, in itself, powerless.
8.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: The entire creation process is driven by Krishna's material nature, which is inherently powerless without Him.

9.original_verse: Winner of Wealth, yet these acts do not bind me; I sit, as one sitting apart, not clinging to these acts.
9.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: Krishna remains detached from the acts of creation, free from any attachment or consequences.

10.original_verse: With me as witness, material nature gives birth to the moving and the still; because of this, Son of Kunti, the world evolves in various ways.
10.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: Krishna witnesses the workings of material nature, which leads to the diverse evolution of the world.

11.original_verse: When I dwell in human form, the confused ones have contempt for me, not knowing my highest nature as the great lord of beings.
11.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: Foolish individuals fail to recognize Krishna's divine nature when He assumes a human form.

12.original_verse: Those thoughtless ones whose hopes, actions and wisdom are all in vain, abide in a fiendish, demonic and deluded nature.
12.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: People engrossed in ignorance and delusion become bound by their demonic tendencies.

13.original_verse: But, Son of Pritha, those whose selves are great, abiding in divine nature, they honour me with a single mind, knowing me as the imperishable one, the beginning of all beings.
13.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: Noble souls recognize Krishna as the eternal source of all and worship Him with focused devotion.

14.original_verse: Continually praising me, striving, their vows firm, honouring me with devotion, eternally joined [to yoga], they worship.
14.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: Devotees engage in constant praise, dedication, and unwavering yoga to honor Krishna.

15.original_verse: And others, through the sacrifice of wisdom, worship me as the oneness which is multiple, placed in many ways, facing all sides.
15.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: Krishna is worshipped as the unity underlying all diversity, through wisdom and recognition of His omnipresence.

16.original_verse: I am the intention; I am the sacrifice; I am the share of offering; I am the healing plant; I am the mantra; I am also heated butter; I am fire; I am the poured oblation.
16.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: Krishna describes Himself as the essence of all sacrifices, offerings, and the divine energy present in all aspects of ritual worship.

17.original_verse: I am the father of the world – its mother, its arranger and its grandfather; I am what is to be known; the purifier; the sound ‘Om’; the Rig, the Sama and the Yajur Veda.
17.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: Krishna declares His universal role as the creator, sustainer, and essence of sacred knowledge found in the Vedas.

18.original_verse: I am the way, the bearer, the great lord, the one who sees. I am home, and shelter, the heart’s companion. I am birth, death and sustenance; I am the house of treasure, and the eternal seed.
18.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: Krishna describes Himself as the ultimate refuge, the eternal source of life, and the guiding presence in all aspects of existence.

19.original_verse: I give off heat, and I am the rain. I hold back, and I send out. I am sweet immortality, as well as death; being and non-being, Arjuna.
19.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: Krishna explains His role as both the life-giving and destructive force, encompassing the dualities of existence.

20.original_verse: Those who know the Vedas and drink Soma, cleansed of their evils seek heaven, and offer to me with sacrifices. They reach the pure world of Indra, and enjoy the divine pleasures of the gods in heaven.
20.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: Krishna describes the rewards of ritualistic worship, which lead to temporary pleasures in celestial realms.

21.original_verse: When they have enjoyed the wide realm of heaven, when their merit is gone, they enter the mortal realm. Then, following the dharma of the three Vedas, they desire their desires. They get what comes and goes.
21.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: Krishna explains the impermanence of heavenly pleasures and the cyclical nature of rebirth tied to karma.

22.original_verse: For beings who honour me, who guide their thoughts to me, and no other, I bring the secure peace of yoga to those who are eternally joined [to yoga].
22.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: Devotion to Krishna leads to eternal peace and liberation, transcending the temporary rewards of rituals.

23.original_verse: Even those who are devoted to other gods, but who sacrifice with trust, they also sacrifice to me, although they do not sacrifice in the right way.
23.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: Krishna acknowledges the devotion of others but emphasizes the importance of worshiping Him directly for liberation.

24.original_verse: I am indeed the enjoyer and the ruler of all sacrifices. But they do not recognize me in reality, so they fall.
24.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: Those unaware of Krishna’s supreme role fail to attain true liberation, despite their sacrifices.

25.original_verse: Those who choose gods go to the gods. Those who choose ancestors go to the ancestors. Those who honour the ghosts go to the ghosts. Those who sacrifice to me go to me.
25.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: Krishna emphasizes that devotion determines one’s spiritual destination, with Him being the ultimate goal.

26.original_verse: Leaf and blossom, fruit and water: from the one who offers these to me with devotion, the one whose self is pure, I take that offering of devotion.
26.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: Krishna values sincere devotion over material offerings, accepting even the simplest gifts with pure intent.

27.original_verse: Son of Kunti, all that you do, all that you take, all that you offer, all that you give, all that you strive for, in heated discipline – do that in offering to me.
27.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: Krishna advises dedicating every action and endeavor as an offering to Him, transforming worldly duties into spiritual acts.

28.original_verse: You will surely be freed from the bonds of action and its fruits, the pure and impure. With your self free, joined to the yoga of renunciation, you will come to me.
28.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: Renunciation of attachment to actions and their results leads to liberation and union with Krishna.

29.original_verse: I am the same in all beings. There is no one whom I hate or love. But those who honour me with devotion, are within me, and I am also in them.
29.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: Krishna expresses His impartiality but affirms the special unity with those devoted to Him.

30.original_verse: If the one who does evil honours me and not another, that one is thought to be good. That one has begun in the right way.
30.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: Even those who have committed wrongs can transform into good beings through sincere devotion to Krishna.

31.original_verse: That one quickly becomes the very self of dharma, and enters eternal peace. Recognize that no one who is devoted to me is ever lost, Son of Kunti.
31.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: Krishna assures that those devoted to Him quickly achieve righteousness and eternal peace, emphasizing the security of His devotees.

32.original_verse: Son of Pritha, those who seek refuge in me, even those who come from evil wombs, or women, vaishyas, even shudras, they, too, go on the highest path.
32.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: Even individuals from humble or marginalized origins can attain the highest spiritual path through devotion to Krishna.

33.original_verse: How much more the pure brahmins and the royal sages are devoted in this way! When you have reached this unhappy realm which perishes, become devoted to me.
33.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: Krishna highlights the natural inclination of the spiritually advanced toward devotion, while urging others to transcend this transient, sorrowful world.

34.original_verse: With your mind on me, be devoted to me; sacrifice to me, and bow with reverence to me. Joined in this way, with me as the highest goal – you will come to me alone.
34.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: Complete surrender, reverence, and focus on Krishna lead the devotee directly to Him as the ultimate goal.

1.original_verse: Strong-Armed One, listen again to my highest word which I will tell you, whom I love, with desire for your well-being.
1.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: Krishna expresses His love and concern for Arjuna, offering to impart supreme knowledge for his ultimate benefit.

2.original_verse: Neither the great throngs of gods nor the great sages know my origin. In all ways, I am truly the beginning of the gods and the sages.
2.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: The origin of Krishna is beyond the understanding of even the greatest sages and gods, as He is the source of all.

3.original_verse: The one who knows me, without birth, without beginning, the great lord of the world, is not confused among mortals; that one is freed from all forms of harm.
3.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: Understanding Krishna as eternal and birthless liberates one from ignorance and worldly delusions.

4.original_verse: Insight, wisdom, freedom from confusion, patience, truth and self-control; peacefulness, pleasure and pain, arising and passing on, fear and courage—
4.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: All states of being, whether virtuous or otherwise, are rooted in Krishna's divine power.

5.original_verse: The many kinds of states of being arise from me alone: not doing harm, equanimity, contentment, heated discipline, giving gifts, fame and infamy.
5.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: All moral and emotional qualities emerge from Krishna, emphasizing His omnipresence.

6.original_verse: In ancient times, the seven great sages and the four Manus, ancestors of humans, and the beings in this world had their origins in me, brought forth by my mind.
6.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: Krishna is the mental originator of ancient sages and Manus, showing His role as the progenitor of life.

7.original_verse: The one who really knows my power and yoga—that one is joined to me in a yoga that does not waver; there is no doubt about this.
7.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: True understanding of Krishna's power leads to unwavering devotion and union with Him.

8.original_verse: I am the origin of all, and all emerges from me. When they think in this way, the insightful ones who are gifted with creative contemplation, are part of me.
8.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: Realizing Krishna as the source of everything aligns insightful beings with His divine essence.

9.original_verse: Those whose thought is focused on me, whose breath goes to me, who awaken each other, and speak about me, become eternally joyful and delighted.
9.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: Devotees of Krishna find eternal joy in their unity and shared devotion to Him.

10.original_verse: They who are always joined to yoga, who are part of me, and filled with kindness, to them I give the yoga of insight. By that yoga, they come to me.
10.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: Krishna grants insight to devoted yogis, enabling them to attain Him through wisdom.

11.original_verse: Since I move in sympathy with them, while dwelling in myself, I destroy their darkness born of ignorance with the bright lamp of wisdom.
11.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: Krishna dispels ignorance with wisdom for those devoted to Him, ensuring their enlightenment.

12.original_verse: You are the highest Brahman, the highest dwelling place, the highest one who purifies, the divine eternal spirit, the first unborn god who pervades all.
12.speaker: Arjuna

commentary.shankaracharya: Arjuna praises Krishna as the supreme being and eternal spirit, acknowledging His divine greatness.

13.original_verse: So all the sages tell you—the heavenly sage Narada, and also Asita Devala, and Vyasa. And now, you tell me so yourself.
13.speaker: Arjuna

commentary.shankaracharya: Arjuna confirms Krishna's divinity as testified by revered sages and now heard directly from Him.

14.original_verse: Lovely-Haired One, I believe all that you say to me is true. No one knows your forms—neither the gods nor the demons, Blessed One.
14.speaker: Arjuna

commentary.shankaracharya: Arjuna expresses unwavering belief in Krishna's words, affirming the incomprehensibility of His forms.

15.original_verse: Highest of spirits, cause of beings, lord of beings, god of gods, ruler of the world, you know your own self through your self alone.
15.speaker: Arjuna

commentary.shankaracharya: Arjuna acknowledges Krishna as the supreme cause and master of creation, comprehensible only by Himself.

16.original_verse: If you will, please tell me, with nothing left out, the divine forms of your own self – the forms by which you pervade all these realms, and dwell in them.
16.speaker: Arjuna

commentary.shankaracharya: Arjuna requests Krishna to reveal His divine manifestations in detail, showing how He pervades and sustains the universe.

17.original_verse: Yogin, as I continually reflect on you, how might I know you? And in what different states of being can I fathom you, Blessed One?
17.speaker: Arjuna

commentary.shankaracharya: Arjuna seeks guidance on understanding Krishna's divine manifestations through different states and forms.

18.original_verse: Mover of Men, tell me again in each detail, about the yoga and the form of your self. I never tire of hearing this nectar.
18.speaker: Arjuna

commentary.shankaracharya: Arjuna expresses his eagerness to learn more about Krishna's divine yoga and forms, describing His teachings as nectar.

19.original_verse: Listen! I will tell you the heavenly forms of my self; I will tell you the primary ones, for there is no end to my extent, Best of the Kurus.
19.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: Krishna begins revealing His primary divine manifestations, emphasizing their endless nature.

20.original_verse: Thick-Haired One, I am the self. I dwell as the refuge of all beings, and I am also the beginning, middle and end of beings.
20.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: Krishna identifies Himself as the self and the refuge, existing through all stages of creation.

21.original_verse: Among the Adityas, I am Vishnu. Among the great lights I am the sun, shining. Among storm gods, the Maruts, I am their chief, Marici. Among stars of the zodiac, I am the rabbit-marked moon.
21.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: Krishna highlights His presence among celestial beings, as Vishnu, the sun, the moon, and chief of the Maruts.

22.original_verse: Among the Vedas, I am the Sama chant. Among the gods, I am Indra, called Vasava. Among the powers of sense, I am the mind. Among beings, I am thought.
22.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: Krishna reveals His divine essence in the Sama chant, Indra, the mind, and as thought itself.

23.original_verse: Among the Rudras, I am Shankara. Among the Yakshas and Rakshas, I am Vittesha, lord of wealth. Among the Vasus, I am fire, the purifier. And among the mountains, I am Meru.
23.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: Krishna identifies with Rudra, Shankara; Kubera, the Yaksha lord of wealth; fire as purifier; and Meru, the mountain.

24.original_verse: Son of Pritha, recognize me as Brihaspati, the head of household priests, the ruler of sacrifice. Among the chief of armies, I am Skanda. Among the waters, I am the ocean.
24.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: Krishna speaks of His manifestations as Brihaspati, Skanda, and the ocean, representing knowledge, valor, and vastness.

25.original_verse: Among great sages, I am Bhrigu. Of things that are uttered, I am the syllable ‘Om’. Among sacrifices, I am the soft recitation. Among things that do not move, I am the Himalaya.
25.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: Krishna aligns Himself with Om, Bhrigu, soft recitation, and the immovable grandeur of the Himalayas.

26.original_verse: Among all the trees, I am the ashvattha fig tree. Among heavenly sages I am Narada. Among the Gandharvas, I am Chief Citraratha. Among those who are fulfilled, I am the wise sage, Kapila.
26.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: Krishna declares His presence in the sacred ashvattha, Narada, Citraratha, and Kapila as symbols of fulfillment and wisdom.

27.original_verse: Among horses, I am Indra’s Uccaihshravas. Recognize me to be born of nectar. Among great elephants, I am Indra’s Airavata. And among men, I am their protector.
27.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: Krishna speaks of His manifestations in divine horses, elephants, and as the protector of men.

28.original_verse: Among weapons, I am the thunderbolt. Among cows, I am the wish-granting cow. I am Kandarpa, who makes progeny. Among serpents, I am their king, Vasuki.
28.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: Krishna highlights His divine presence in Vasuki, the thunderbolt, Kandarpa, and the wish-granting cow.

29.original_verse: Among snakes, I am the endless one. Among sea creatures, I am Varuna. Among ancestors, I am Aryaman, their chief. Among those who snuff out [life], I am Yama, god of death.
29.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: Krishna reveals His divinity in Varuna, Aryaman, and Yama, representing eternity, tradition, and death.

30.original_verse: Among the Daityas, I am their prince Prahlada. Among those who count, I am time itself. Among the animals, I am the lion, their Lord. And among the birds, I am Vainateya.
30.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: Krishna identifies as Prahlada among Daityas, time itself, the lion among animals, and Garuda among birds.

31.original_verse: Among purifiers, I am the wind. Among those who bear weapons, I am Rama. Among sea monsters, I am Makara, the crocodile. Among rivers, I am Ganges, Jahnu’s daughter.
31.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: Krishna identifies Himself with purifying forces, valor, and revered natural elements like the Ganges.

32.original_verse: Arjuna, among creations, I am the first, last and middle. Among insights, I am insight into the highest self. Among those who speak, I am discourse.
32.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: Krishna describes Himself as the essence of creation, self-awareness, and meaningful communication.

33.original_verse: Among imperishable sounds, I am the letter ‘A’. Among words joined together, I am the simple link. I alone am imperishable time; I am the arranger, facing everywhere.
33.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: Krishna signifies the eternal, fundamental essence of sound, time, and universal order.

34.original_verse: I am death, who seizes all, and the beginning of that which will be. Among female deities, I am Good Name, Wealth and Speech, Memory, Intelligence, Constancy, Endurance.
34.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: Krishna embodies transformative forces like death and the virtues represented by revered female deities.

35.original_verse: Among chants, I am the great chant to Indra. Among metres, I am the perfect Gayatri. Among months, I am Margashirsha. Among seasons, I am blossoming spring.
35.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: Krishna aligns Himself with the most auspicious prayers, time periods, and seasons.

36.original_verse: Among those who cheat, I am risk. Among the brilliant, I am brilliance. I am victory; I am resolve. Among those who possess the truth, I am truth.
36.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: Krishna emphasizes His identity with boldness, clarity, and ultimate truth.

37.original_verse: Among the Vrishni people, I am Krishna Vasudeva. Among the Pandavas, I’m Arjuna, winner of wealth. Among wise ones, I am the author Vyasa. Among poets, I am the poet Ushanas.
37.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: Krishna reveals Himself as key figures of wisdom, valor, and artistic excellence.

38.original_verse: Among rulers with the sceptre, I am authority. Among those who want victory, I am wise conduct. Among hidden things, I am silence. Among the wise, I am wisdom.
38.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: Krishna highlights qualities like authority, wisdom, and the power of silence.

39.original_verse: Arjuna, among all beings, I am the seed. There is no creature, moving or unmoving, that would be without me.
39.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: Krishna describes Himself as the seed of all creation, the source of everything that exists.

40.original_verse: Scorcher of the Enemy, there is no end to my divine forms. Here indeed, example by example, I have declared this, the true expanse of my power.
40.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: Krishna’s infinite divine forms cannot be fully enumerated; He provides examples of His vast power.

41.original_verse: Understand that whatever powerful being there is – be it splendid, or filled with vigour, it comes to be from only a small part of my brilliance.
41.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: All splendor and power in the world are mere fractions of Krishna's divine brilliance.

42.original_verse: But what, Arjuna, is the purpose of this abundant wisdom to you? I stand, holding up this entire world with only a small part of my self.
42.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: Krishna emphasizes that even a fraction of His power sustains the entire universe.

1.original_verse: In kindness to me, you have uttered the highest mystery, recognized as the highest self. With your words, my confusion is gone.
1.speaker: Arjuna

commentary.shankaracharya: Arjuna expresses gratitude for Krishna revealing the highest truth, which has alleviated his confusion.

2.original_verse: Lotus-Eyed One, I have heard from you in detail of two things: the beginning and end of beings, and also your imperishable greatness.
2.speaker: Arjuna

commentary.shankaracharya: Arjuna acknowledges Krishna's teachings on the creation and dissolution of beings and the eternal nature of Krishna.

3.original_verse: Supreme Lord, thus it is as you yourself say it. Now I want to see your lordly form, Highest Spirit.
3.speaker: Arjuna

commentary.shankaracharya: Arjuna, having understood Krishna’s divine teachings, now seeks to witness Krishna’s supreme form.

4.original_verse: Master, Lord of Yoga, if you think I am able to see this, then show yourself to me, you who are the imperishable one.
4.speaker: Arjuna

commentary.shankaracharya: Arjuna requests Krishna to reveal His true form, acknowledging His power as the imperishable supreme being.

5.original_verse: Son of Pritha, see my divine forms, a hundred, a thousand kinds – all different, all divine, and in many colours and shapes.
5.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: Krishna responds, inviting Arjuna to witness His infinite divine forms, showcasing His boundless power and nature.

6.original_verse: See the Adityas, the Vasus, the Rudras, the twin Ashvins, and the Maruts – these many wonders which have never been seen before, Son of Bharata.
6.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: Krishna reveals the divine beings and cosmic powers that Arjuna is about to witness in His supreme form.

7.original_verse: See now the whole world, with all things moving and unmoving standing together in my body, and anything else you would like to see, Thick-Haired One.
7.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: Krishna displays His universal form, where all beings and phenomena exist simultaneously within His body.

8.original_verse: But you are not able to see with your own eye, so I will give to you the divine eye; see my powerful yoga.
8.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: Since Arjuna cannot perceive Krishna's divine form with ordinary vision, Krishna grants him divine sight to witness the extraordinary.

9.original_verse: Your Majesty, when he said this, Hari, the great lord of yoga, showed to Arjuna the Son of Pritha his highest, most powerful, form.
9.speaker: Sanjaya

commentary.shankaracharya: Sanjaya narrates the moment when Krishna revealed His supreme form to Arjuna, marking a divine revelation.

10.original_verse: It had many mouths and eyes; many wondrous aspects to behold; many divine ornaments; many divine weapons of war, raised high.
10.speaker: Sanjaya

commentary.shankaracharya: The form Krishna reveals to Arjuna is overwhelming, with countless features, ornaments, and weapons, symbolizing the infinite powers of Krishna.

11.original_verse: Bearing divine garlands and garments, divine scents and oils, the god held every wonder – facing everywhere, without end.
11.speaker: Sanjaya

commentary.shankaracharya: Krishna’s form is adorned with divine attributes, symbolizing His limitless reach and presence in all directions.

12.original_verse: If a thousand suns had risen in the sky all at once, such brilliance would be the brilliance of that great self.
12.speaker: Sanjaya

commentary.shankaracharya: The radiance of Krishna’s universal form is so intense that it surpasses the brilliance of a thousand suns.

13.original_verse: There, Arjuna, the son of Pandu, saw in the body of the God of gods the whole world, standing as one, and yet divided up in many ways.
13.speaker: Sanjaya

commentary.shankaracharya: Arjuna perceives the entire universe as one within Krishna’s form, with the infinite diversity of existence contained within Him.

14.original_verse: Then Arjuna, winner of wealth, was seized by awe; his hair stood on end. Bowing, with folded hands, with his head bent towards the god, he said:
14.speaker: Sanjaya

commentary.shankaracharya: Arjuna is awestruck by Krishna’s supreme form, filled with reverence and humility.

15.original_verse: I see the gods in your body, and all kinds of beings gathered together: Lord Brahma, seated in a lotus, all the sages and all the divine serpents.
15.speaker: Arjuna

commentary.shankaracharya: Arjuna witnesses the presence of all divine beings and sages within Krishna’s cosmic form.

16.original_verse: I see you everywhere: arms, bellies, faces, eyes – form without end. I see you, Lord of the Universe, Manifold One, you have no beginning, no middle, no end.
16.speaker: Arjuna

commentary.shankaracharya: Arjuna sees Krishna's infinite, all-encompassing form, with no start, middle, or end, reflecting His divine nature.

17.original_verse: I see you, who are hard to see, completely, beyond measure. With the light of a sun whose fire is blazing, you shine everywhere – a mountain of light, with crown, club and discus.
17.speaker: Arjuna

commentary.shankaracharya: Arjuna perceives Krishna's radiance, akin to a blazing sun, shining omnipresently with divine weapons in hand.

18.original_verse: You are to be known as the highest, unchanging; you are the great refuge of all, you are the imperishable, eternal protector of dharma. I know your spirit to be ancient.
18.speaker: Arjuna

commentary.shankaracharya: Arjuna acknowledges Krishna as the eternal, unchanging protector of dharma, embodying the imperishable nature of the universe.

19.original_verse: I see you, with endless vital power, endless arms, eyes of the sun and moon, your mouth taking in fiery offerings, scorching all this world with your own light.
19.speaker: Arjuna

commentary.shankaracharya: Arjuna perceives Krishna's infinite power, with divine attributes that symbolize the sun and moon, consuming everything in His flame.

20.original_verse: This realm between earth and sky is filled by you at every point; when the three worlds see your wondrous and awful form, they start to tremble, Great Self.
20.speaker: Arjuna

commentary.shankaracharya: Krishna's presence fills the entire cosmos, causing all realms to tremble in awe and reverence before His wondrous form.

21.original_verse: There, great gatherings of gods enter you. Some sing praise, fearful, with folded hands. When the gatherings of fulfilled beings and great sages say, ‘Svasti!’ they praise you with many songs.
21.speaker: Arjuna

commentary.shankaracharya: Even the gods and sages, overwhelmed by Krishna's form, offer praises and prayers in reverence to Him.

22.original_verse: They all see you, truly amazed: the Rudras, the Adityas, the Vasus, and the Sadhyas; the All-gods; the two Ashvins; the Maruts; the Drinkers of Steam; the groups of Gandharvas, the Yakshas, the Demons, and those who are fulfilled.
22.speaker: Arjuna

commentary.shankaracharya: Arjuna describes how even the highest beings, from gods to sages, gaze upon Krishna in awe, recognizing His divine supremacy.

23.original_verse: Strong-Armed One, when the worlds see your great form, with many eyes and mouths, many arms, thighs and feet, with many fearsome tusks and many bellies, they tremble as I do.
23.speaker: Arjuna

commentary.shankaracharya: Arjuna expresses his fear and amazement at Krishna's terrifying, multi-formed cosmic presence.

24.original_verse: Vishnu, since I have seen you ablaze with many colours, touching the sky, flames in your huge eyes, your mouth gaping, my self trembles and I find neither courage nor calm.
24.speaker: Arjuna

commentary.shankaracharya: The overwhelming sight of Krishna's divine form, with his blazing colors and fiery presence, leaves Arjuna shaken and devoid of courage.

25.original_verse: Show compassion, Lord of Gods, Abode of the World! When I have seen your faces with many fearsome tusks, so much like the fires at the end of time, I do not know the way, and I find no refuge.
25.speaker: Arjuna

commentary.shankaracharya: Arjuna, overwhelmed by Krishna's form, pleads for mercy, as he sees the destructive power of Krishna resembling the end of time.

26.original_verse: And all these sons of Dhritarashtra, alongside the gatherings of kings Bhishma, Drona and Karna, son of the charioteer, together with our chief warriors, too,
26.speaker: Arjuna

commentary.shankaracharya: Arjuna witnesses the warriors of both sides entering Krishna's terrifying mouth, symbolizing their imminent destruction.

27.original_verse: all in a rush, they enter your terrible mouths, gaping with tusks. Some appear with heads crushed, clinging between your teeth.
27.speaker: Arjuna

commentary.shankaracharya: Arjuna envisions the gruesome fate of warriors being consumed by Krishna's form, as if trapped in His mighty jaws.

28.original_verse: The heroes of the mortal world enter your flaming mouths, as so many currents of water in a river might run towards the ocean.
28.speaker: Arjuna

commentary.shankaracharya: The warriors' swift destruction is likened to a river flowing into the ocean, symbolizing the inevitability of their fate.

29.original_verse: As moths that fly to their full will rush to death in the blazing fire, so, too, worlds rush to death in your mouths.
29.speaker: Arjuna

commentary.shankaracharya: The helplessness of beings is compared to moths rushing into the fire, destined for death in Krishna's cosmic form.

30.original_verse: Vishnu, your mouths, their flames licking the worlds, devour on all sides. Your fierce rays burn the earth, even as they fill it with light.
30.speaker: Arjuna

commentary.shankaracharya: Krishna's cosmic form, with its fiery rays, destroys the world while simultaneously illuminating it with divine light.

31.original_verse: Tell me who you are in your terrible form. May you be honoured, Chosen of the Gods. Show compassion! I want to know you, Primal One; I do not understand your activity.
31.speaker: Arjuna

commentary.shankaracharya: Arjuna, overcome by the overwhelming form of Krishna, seeks to understand the true nature and purpose of Krishna's divine manifestation.

32.original_verse: I am time that has aged, who makes the world perish. I have come forth to destroy the worlds. Even without you, these warriors facing off against each other will no longer exist.
32.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: Krishna reveals Himself as time, the ultimate force of dissolution, responsible for the destruction of the world and the inevitability of death.

33.original_verse: So stand up, and gain honour! After conquering enemies, enjoy an abundant reign. I’ve already destroyed them. You who sling arrows from the left and the right, be an instrument, and nothing more.
33.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: Krishna encourages Arjuna to fight without hesitation, as the outcome is already decided by Krishna's will.

34.original_verse: All these heroes of battle, Drona, Bhishma, Jayadratha and Karna, have been struck down by me. Do not be troubled, but strike! Fight! For you will conquer enemies in battle.
34.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: Krishna assures Arjuna that the battle is already won by divine will and that Arjuna is merely the instrument of victory.

35.original_verse: When he heard the words of the lovely-haired god, Arjuna, trembling despite his kingly crown, his hands folded, fearful, and bowing down, spoke to Krishna again.
35.speaker: Sanjaya

commentary.shankaracharya: Sanjaya narrates Arjuna's emotional reaction to Krishna's words, where Arjuna is overcome by awe and fear of Krishna's overwhelming form.

36.original_verse: Bristling-Haired One, it is right that the world exults, delighting in your fame; that the demons are fearful, and flee all places; and that the gatherings of fulfilled beings honour you.
36.speaker: Arjuna

commentary.shankaracharya: Arjuna acknowledges Krishna's divine power and the reverence He commands from both gods and demons.

37.original_verse: And why, Great Self, would they not bow to you, the first maker? Endless lord of gods, greater than Brahma, abode of the world, undying, existent, non-existent, and yet beyond.
37.speaker: Arjuna

commentary.shankaracharya: Arjuna marvels at Krishna’s supreme nature, acknowledging Him as the eternal origin of all creation, beyond all limits and descriptions.

38.original_verse: You are the highest abode of all the universe, the god in the beginning, the spirit of old, You are the knower, and that which is to be known. All is pervaded by you, One of Endless Form!
38.speaker: Arjuna

commentary.shankaracharya: Arjuna praises Krishna as the source and sustainer of all existence, the ultimate truth that transcends all.

39.original_verse: You are Vayu, Yama, Agni, Varuna, the rabbit-marked moon, the lord of creatures, the first great-grandfather. May honour be made to you a thousand times, and yet again. Honour to you!
39.speaker: Arjuna

commentary.shankaracharya: Arjuna enumerates various divine aspects of Krishna, recognizing His omnipresence and transcendence across all deities.

40.original_verse: Honour to you, before you and behind you; honour to you on all sides! You who are all, you are force without measure, endless courage. Since you reach all, you are all.
40.speaker: Arjuna

commentary.shankaracharya: Arjuna acknowledges Krishna’s all-encompassing presence and limitless power, offering his respect and devotion from all directions.

41.original_verse: I was in ignorance about your majesty when I said hastily ‘O Krishna of the Yadu, O Friend!’ I was thinking as a friend would – in confusion, and also love.
41.speaker: Arjuna

commentary.shankaracharya: Arjuna humbly admits his ignorance and improper understanding of Krishna’s supreme nature, recognizing the divine beyond their friendship.

42.original_verse: If you were badly treated, in jest, eating or sitting, lying in bed or in play, alone or even in front of others, I ask your pardon, Immeasurable, Unshakeable One!
42.speaker: Arjuna

commentary.shankaracharya: Arjuna asks for forgiveness for any unintentional disrespect shown to Krishna, acknowledging Krishna's immensity and unshakable nature.

43.original_verse: You are father of the world, of the moving and the still – its weighty, honoured teacher. There is no one like you in the three worlds. How can there be another who is greater, Incomparable One?
43.speaker: Arjuna

commentary.shankaracharya: Arjuna praises Krishna as the supreme father, teacher, and the one incomparable in all the worlds.

44.original_verse: Thus bowing with body laid down, I ask your mercy, Praiseworthy Lord. Have patience, God, as a father for a son, or a friend for a friend, a lover for a beloved.
44.speaker: Arjuna

commentary.shankaracharya: Arjuna bows before Krishna, seeking His mercy, comparing Krishna’s love to the care of a father, friend, and lover.

45.original_verse: I have seen what has never before been seen. I am filled with delight; my mind is shaken with fear. God, let me see the form [I know]! Lord of Gods, Abode of the Earth, show compassion.
45.speaker: Arjuna

commentary.shankaracharya: Arjuna, having seen Krishna's universal form, is both in awe and fear, desiring to return to the more familiar form of Krishna.

46.original_verse: I would like to see you in that form, with crown and club and discus in hand. Thousand-Armed One, One Who has All Shapes, take on that four-armed form!
46.speaker: Arjuna

commentary.shankaracharya: Arjuna requests Krishna to reveal His divine, awe-inspiring four-armed form, which symbolizes the highest aspect of divinity.

47.original_verse: Arjuna, in favour to you, I showed this highest form through my own yoga. No one other than you has seen this before; it is made of light, endless, primordial.
47.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: Krishna reveals that this divine form, unique to Arjuna, is of primordial, infinite light and is shown to him by His divine yoga.

48.original_verse: Neither by Vedic study nor Vedic sacrifice, nor ritual actions, nor gifts, nor heated disciplines, can I be seen in this form in the human realm by anyone other than you, Brave Kuru.
48.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: Krishna explains that this divine form cannot be perceived by ordinary means, such as Vedic rituals, except by those He chooses.

49.original_verse: So do not tremble and do not be confused; you have seen my awe-inspiring form, and your dread disappeared, your mind encouraged. See again this form of mine [that you know].
49.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: Krishna reassures Arjuna, telling him not to be frightened by the terrifying vision, and to focus on His familiar, gentle form.

50.original_verse: After he spoke to Arjuna, the son of Vasudeva showed his own form again, and he calmed Arjuna’s dread when the great self once again took on a pleasing, gentle appearance.
50.speaker: Sanjaya

commentary.shankaracharya: Sanjaya narrates how Krishna reassured Arjuna by revealing His calming, familiar form after the terrifying divine vision.

51.original_verse: Mover of Men, as I see this, your gentle human form, I am now composed. My thoughts have returned to a natural state.
51.speaker: Arjuna

commentary.shankaracharya: Arjuna expresses his relief upon seeing Krishna in His human form, which brings him back to a state of composure and clarity.

52.original_verse: The form of mine which you have seen is hard to discern. Even the gods are eternally wanting to have the sacred sight of this form.
52.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: Krishna tells Arjuna that His divine form is beyond ordinary comprehension and even the gods yearn to witness it.

53.original_verse: Neither through Veda, nor heated discipline, nor gift, nor sacrifice, is it possible to see me in the way you have seen me.
53.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: Krishna emphasizes that His true form cannot be understood or seen through rituals or disciplines, only through divine grace.

54.original_verse: Arjuna, I can only be known by devotion that has no other object. In this way, may I be truly known and seen and reached, Scorcher of the Enemy.
54.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: Krishna explains that the only way to truly know Him is through single-minded devotion, which leads to union with the divine.

55.original_verse: The one who acts on my behalf, who holds me as highest, who is devoted to me, who lets go of clinging and is free from hatred towards all beings, comes to me, Son of Pandu.
55.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: Krishna explains that the ultimate path to liberation is through selfless service, detachment, and love for all beings.

1.original_verse: Arjuna said: Between the ones who are always joined to yoga, and honour you with devotion, and the ones who honour the imperishable one, the one without form, who is the wisest about yoga?
1.speaker: Arjuna

commentary.shankaracharya: Arjuna asks Krishna who is the better practitioner of yoga: those devoted to His form or those devoted to the formless Brahman.

2.original_verse: The Blessed One said: Those who are eternally joined to yoga, and who honour me with the mind fixed on me, and gifted with the highest trust, I think of them as the most joined to yoga.
2.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: Krishna answers that those devoted to Him with full trust and concentration are the highest in yoga.

3.original_verse: But those who honour the imperishable one, who is undefinable, and without form, who pervades all and is beyond thought, unmoving, steady, as if fixed on a mountaintop,
3.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: Krishna describes those who worship the formless and imperishable Brahman, highlighting their dedication.

4.original_verse: and those whose many senses are reined in together, with equal insight in all places, and who exult in the good of all beings, also reach me.
4.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: Those who control their senses, see all beings equally, and act for the welfare of others also reach Krishna.

5.original_verse: The pain of those whose thought focuses on the one without form is greater. The goal of the one without form is hard to reach for those with bodies.
5.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: The difficulty of focusing on the formless is greater for those with physical bodies, and it brings greater hardship.

6.original_verse: But those who give up all actions to me, who hold me as highest, and with yoga where the goal is clear, in pure concentration, they honour me.
6.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: Those who dedicate all actions to Krishna, placing Him as the highest goal, and practice yoga with clear focus, honor Him in the truest sense.

7.original_verse: Son of Pritha, for those whose thoughts have entered into me, I will very soon become their uplifter from the ocean of death and rebirth.
7.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: Krishna promises to elevate those whose thoughts are devoted to Him, freeing them from the cycle of birth and death.

8.original_verse: Place your mind on me alone; let your power of insight enter into me. Then doubtless, from now on, you will abide in me.
8.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: Krishna urges Arjuna to concentrate his mind on Him alone, and by doing so, he will surely be united with Him.

9.original_verse: If you cannot put your thought steadily on me, then you should seek to reach me through the practice of yoga, Winner of Wealth.
9.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: Krishna suggests that if Arjuna cannot focus his mind on Him, he should pursue yoga to reach Him.

10.original_verse: If you are not able even to practise, then be focused on my work. Also, while doing actions for my sake, you will reach fulfilment.
10.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: If yoga practice is not possible, Krishna advises Arjuna to dedicate his actions to Him, which will lead to spiritual fulfillment.

11.original_verse: Or, if you are unable to do even this, take refuge in my power, leaving aside all fruit of action. Act from that place, holding back the self.
11.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: If all else fails, Krishna tells Arjuna to surrender to His divine power, renouncing the results of actions and focusing on self-restraint.

12.original_verse: Wisdom is better than practice, and focused mind is better than wisdom. Letting go of the fruit of action is better than focused mind. From letting go, peace soon comes.
12.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: Krishna extols the importance of renouncing the fruits of actions, stating that peace follows detachment more swiftly than intense concentration.

13.original_verse: One who has no hatred for any being, a compassionate friend, without the sense of ‘mine’, without making an ‘I’, one who is patient, for whom pain and pleasure are the same,
13.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: The ideal yogi is one who harbors no hatred, is patient, treats all beings with compassion, and is unaffected by pain or pleasure.

14.original_verse: that practitioner of yoga who is always content, whose self is controlled, and whose resolve is firm, whose power of insight and mind are fixed on me, who is devoted to me, that one is dear to me.
14.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: Krishna describes the ideal devotee as one who is content, self-controlled, determined, and always devoted to Him.

15.original_verse: The one in whose presence the world does not tremble, and who does not tremble in the presence of the world, who is free from pleasure and impatience, fear and anxiety, is also dear to me.
15.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: The yogi who is unaffected by external circumstances, free from fear, anxiety, and impatience, and remains unshaken, is especially dear to Krishna.

16.original_verse: The one who is able, pure and impartial, who sits apart, whose anxiety is gone, who leaves off all endeavours, who is devoted to me, is dear to me.
16.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: A person who is free from anxiety, detached from worldly endeavours, and devoted to Krishna is cherished by Him.

17.original_verse: The one who neither rejoices nor resents, neither sorrows nor lusts, letting go of states both happy and unhappy, filled with devotion, is dear to me.
17.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: True devotion comes from emotional balance, not swayed by joy or sorrow, pain or pleasure.

18.original_verse: The one for whom enemy and friend, honour and infamy, cold and heat, pleasure and pain, are the same, who has moved away from clinging,
18.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: The one who perceives no difference between friend and foe, or pain and pleasure, has transcended attachment and clinging.

19.original_verse: the one for whom curse and praise are equal, who keeps silent, content with whatsoever comes his way, without home, with steady mind, full of devotion, that one is dear to me.
19.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: True devotion is expressed by those who are unaffected by external praise or blame, remain silent and content in all circumstances.

20.original_verse: Those who honour that nectar of dharma spoken in this way, holding trust, holding me as highest, devoted to me, are very dear to me.
20.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: Those who follow the path of righteousness with trust and devotion, considering Krishna as the highest, are especially dear to Him.

1.original_verse: Arjuna said: Lovely-Haired One, I want to know matter and spirit; the sacred ground, and those who know the sacred ground; wisdom, and the object of wisdom.
1.speaker: Arjuna

commentary.shankaracharya: Arjuna seeks clarity on the distinction between the material (kṣetra) and the spiritual (kṣetrajña) and their relationship to wisdom.

2.original_verse: Son of Kunti, this body is the sacred ground. The wise ones say the one who knows this is the one called the knower of the sacred ground.
2.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: Krishna explains that the body is the field (kṣetra), and the Self that perceives and knows it is the knower of the field (kṣetrajña).

3.original_verse: Son of Bharata, recognize also that I am the one who knows the sacred ground in all sacred grounds. Knowledge of [both] sacred ground and the knower of sacred ground – that I consider wisdom.
3.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: Krishna reveals Himself as the universal knower across all fields, emphasizing that true wisdom encompasses both the field and its knower.

4.original_verse: Hear from me in brief what this sacred ground is and what its nature is; what its transformations are and where they arise from; hear also who the knower is and the knower’s power.
4.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: Krishna introduces the detailed discussion of the field (body) and its transformations, as well as the power of the knower (Self).

5.original_verse: The gross elements, the awareness of ‘I’, the power of insight, and that beyond form; the eleven powers of sense; and the five arenas where the senses act;
5.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: Krishna lists the components of the field, including the physical elements, ego, intellect, and sensory powers, showing the complexity of the field.

6.original_verse: desire, hatred, pleasure and pain, the whole body, the power of thought, and of firmness: this is the sacred ground explained in brief, with its examples.
6.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: The field also includes emotional and mental experiences like desire, aversion, and resolve, reflecting its dynamic nature.

7.original_verse: Absence of arrogance, absence of deceit, absence of harm, patience and virtue, sitting with one’s teacher, purity, steadiness, and the restraint of the self;
7.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: Krishna describes virtues that lead to knowledge, including humility, truthfulness, and self-control, which refine the field.

8.original_verse: indifference to the objects of sense; and the absence of awareness of ‘I’; holding in mind the wrongs of pain, illness, old age, birth and death;
8.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: Detachment from sensory pleasures and awareness of life's suffering are vital steps toward liberation.

9.original_verse: absence of clinging, absence of grasping to things, such as home, wife and child; and eternally with thoughts which are even-minded towards desired and undesired events;
9.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: Freedom from attachment to possessions and relationships, coupled with equanimity, leads to inner peace.

10.original_verse: not fond of crowds of people, resorting to a place apart, without straying from devotion to me, and with no other form of yoga;
10.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: Krishna advises solitude and unwavering devotion as paths to deepen one’s focus on the Supreme.

11.original_verse: being eternally in the wisdom of the supreme self, holding in mind the aim of the wisdom of truth: this is declared as true wisdom, and its contrary is ignorance.
11.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: True wisdom arises from self-realization and unwavering focus on the ultimate truth.

12.original_verse: I will tell you what should be known; and knowing it, one gains immortality. It is the highest Brahman, without beginning, said to be neither being nor non-being.
12.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: Krishna introduces Brahman, the eternal reality beyond dualistic concepts, as the ultimate knowledge leading to immortality.

13.original_verse: This has a hand and foot in all places, and an eye, face and head in all places. In the world, it has hearing in all places; it is present, pervading all.
13.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: Brahman is all-pervading, manifesting through all forms and senses, yet remaining transcendent.

14.original_verse: It has the semblance of all the gunas, yet it is turned away from the senses. It does not cling, and yet bears all. It has no gunas and yet partakes of them.
14.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: Although Brahman is beyond the gunas (qualities), it sustains them and remains unaffected by them.

15.original_verse: It is both inside and outside beings, moving and unmoving. It is not to be comprehended because of its subtlety; it stands far off and also nearby.
15.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: Brahman exists simultaneously within and beyond all, elusive due to its subtle nature.

16.original_verse: Among beings, it is not separate, yet it stands as if separated, and should be known as the bearer of beings. It is the absorber and creator.
16.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: Brahman appears distinct within beings while being inseparable. It supports all beings and acts as both the creator and absorber of existence.

17.original_verse: It is said, too, to be the light of lights; it is said to be beyond darkness; it is known as wisdom and the goal of wisdom. It is seated in the heart of all.
17.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: Brahman is the source of all illumination, transcends ignorance, and resides in every heart as the ultimate goal of wisdom.

18.original_verse: This is the sacred ground, and the wisdom, and the object of wisdom, briefly spoken. When one who is devoted to me comprehends this, that one enters my state of being.
18.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: Krishna emphasizes that understanding the nature of the field, wisdom, and Brahman leads a devotee to liberation and unity with Him.

19.original_verse: Recognize, too, that both spirit and matter are without beginning. And recognize that the transformations and gunas arise from matter.
19.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: Spirit (Purusha) and matter (Prakriti) are eternal. Transformations and qualities emerge from the interplay of matter.

20.original_verse: ‘Matter’ is said to be the reason for the agency of cause and effect, and ‘spirit’ is said to be the reason for the experience of pleasure and pain.
20.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: Matter facilitates actions and consequences, while spirit experiences the resulting pleasures and pains.

21.original_verse: Spirit abides in matter and partakes of the gunas, born of matter. Clinging to the gunas, it is the cause of its birth in wombs, of being and non-being.
21.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: The spirit interacts with matter and its qualities, leading to cycles of birth and death through attachment to the gunas.

22.original_verse: The highest spirit in this body is also called the highest self, the great lord, the one who partakes, who supports, who approves, and who observes.
22.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: Krishna refers to the Supreme Self as the observer, supporter, and guide within all beings.

23.original_verse: The one who recognizes matter and spirit, together with the gunas, is not ever born again, no matter what way one already exists.
23.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: Understanding the distinction between matter, spirit, and the gunas leads to liberation from the cycle of birth and death.

24.original_verse: Some see the self in the self, through the self, by meditation. Others see it through the yoga of samkhya. And others see it through the yoga of action.
24.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: Different paths—meditation, knowledge, and action—reveal the Self based on the practitioner's nature and approach.

25.original_verse: But some do not know in this way, and when they have heard from others, they worship, and also cross beyond death, devoted to that revelation.
25.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: Even those who lack direct understanding but have faith in revealed wisdom can transcend mortality through devotion.

26.original_verse: Bull of the Bharatas, recognize that when any being, moving or still, is born, it is from the union of the sacred ground and the one who knows the sacred ground.
26.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: The interaction of matter (field) and spirit (knower of the field) results in the birth of all beings.

27.original_verse: The one who sees the highest lord, abiding alike in all beings, not dying even as they die, that one truly sees.
27.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: Seeing the undying Supreme Self in all beings is the essence of true vision and wisdom.

28.original_verse: Seeing the same lord existing everywhere, that one does not do harm to the self through the self; that one then goes along the highest way.
28.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: Realizing the universal presence of the Supreme leads to non-violence and alignment with the path to liberation.

29.original_verse: One who sees all actions done wholly by means of matter, and that one’s own self is not the agent, that one sees clearly.
29.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: True understanding comes from realizing that actions are governed by matter, while the Self remains uninvolved.

30.original_verse: When one sees the multiplicity of states of being abiding in one, and spreading out from that one alone, one then arrives at Brahman.
30.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: All diversity stems from the unity of Brahman; realizing this truth leads to self-realization.

31.original_verse: Son of Kunti, because this highest, imperishable self has no beginning, and no gunas, it neither acts nor is stained, even though abiding in the body.
31.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: The Self is eternal, without qualities (gunas), and remains unaffected by actions or impurities despite residing in the body.

32.original_verse: Just as space pervades all, and yet because of its subtlety is not stained, everywhere the self, while abiding in the body, is not stained.
32.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: Krishna compares the Self to space, which pervades everything yet remains untouched, highlighting the purity and transcendence of the Self.

33.original_verse: Son of Bharata, as a single sun lights up this whole realm, so, too, the one who dwells in the sacred ground lights up this whole sacred ground.
33.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: The indwelling Self illuminates the entire field (body and mind), just as the sun illuminates the world, signifying the Self as the source of awareness.

34.original_verse: The ones who know through the eye of wisdom the difference between sacred ground and the knower of sacred ground, and the freedom of matter from being, they go to the highest.
34.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: Realizing the distinction between the field (body) and its knower (Self) through wisdom leads to liberation and unity with the Supreme.

1.original_verse: I will tell you again the highest wisdom; when the sages came to know this utmost wisdom, they went from here to the highest fulfilment.
1.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: Krishna introduces the supreme wisdom that leads to liberation, emphasizing its transformative power as realized by sages.

2.original_verse: After they have arrived at this wisdom, the same essence as myself, they do not come into being at the creation, nor do they tremble at the dissolution.
2.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: Those who attain unity with the divine essence transcend cycles of creation and destruction, achieving eternal liberation.

3.original_verse: Son of Bharata, the great Brahman is my womb; in this I place the embryo. From that emerges the origin of all beings.
3.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: Krishna describes Brahman as the source of all creation, likened to a womb where the seed of existence is placed.

4.original_verse: Son of Kunti, Brahman is the great womb of all forms that exist; I am the father who places the seeds.
4.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: Krishna positions Himself as the active principle that initiates creation, with Brahman as the sustaining source.

5.original_verse: Strong-Armed One, sattva, rajas and tamas are gunas born of matter; they bind the embodied, imperishable one within the body.
5.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: The gunas, or qualities of nature, arise from matter and bind the eternal Self to the physical body.

6.original_verse: Blameless One, there sattva is stainless and brings light; it binds by connection to joy, and by connection to wisdom.
6.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: Sattva, the purest quality, promotes clarity and joy but can bind through attachment to knowledge and happiness.

7.original_verse: Son of Kunti, recognize that rajas has the nature of passion arising from connection to thirst; it binds this embodied one through connection to action.
7.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: Rajas is characterized by desire and action, binding the Self through restless activity and craving.

8.original_verse: Son of Bharata, recognize that tamas is born of ignorance, and is the confusion of all embodied ones; it binds through sleep, laziness and distraction.
8.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: Tamas, arising from ignorance, deludes beings through inertia and lack of clarity, leading to inaction.

9.original_verse: Son of Bharata, sattva brings connection to joy; rajas brings connection to action; tamas brings connection to neglect, and obscures wisdom.
9.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: Each guna has distinct effects: sattva illuminates, rajas incites activity, and tamas obscures understanding.

10.original_verse: Son of Bharata, sattva ascends when it prevails over rajas and tamas; rajas can prevail over sattva and tamas; tamas can prevail over sattva and rajas.
10.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: The gunas compete for dominance, shaping the individual's state of mind and actions.

11.original_verse: When a light is born in all doorways of this body, and when wisdom occurs, then one should know that sattva has grown strong.
11.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: The predominance of sattva manifests as wisdom and clarity, illuminating the individual’s perception.

12.original_verse: Bull of the Bharatas, greed, exertion, the beginning of action, restlessness and lust are born when rajas has grown strong.
12.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: The dominance of rajas leads to excessive desire, restlessness, and compulsive action.

13.original_verse: Son of Kuru, absence of light, absence of exertion, neglect, and confusion are born when tamas has grown strong.
13.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: Tamas manifests as darkness and inertia, hindering progress and causing delusion.

14.original_verse: When sattva has grown strong, the embodied one goes to dissolution; then one enters the stainless realms of those who know the highest.
14.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: A sattvic state at death leads to realms of purity and knowledge, paving the way for liberation.

15.original_verse: When [at death] one dissolves in rajas, one is born among those clinging to action; when [at death] one dissolves in tamas, one is born in the wombs of the deluded.
15.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: Death in rajas results in rebirth among the action-driven, while tamas leads to lives of delusion.

16.original_verse: They say that action well done has fruit without stain, filled with sattva; but the fruit of rajas is pain, and the fruit of tamas is ignorance.
16.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: Actions born of sattva produce pure and beneficial results, while rajas leads to dissatisfaction, and tamas results in ignorance and inertia.

17.original_verse: From sattva, wisdom is born, and from rajas, greed is born; neglect, confusion and ignorance arise from tamas.
17.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: Each guna produces distinct outcomes: sattva fosters clarity, rajas incites desire, and tamas causes delusion and ignorance.

18.original_verse: The ones who abide in sattva rise up; the ones who have rajas abide in the middle; the ones who abide in the lowest guna state, those who have tamas, go downward.
18.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: The predominance of sattva elevates individuals spiritually, rajas keeps them engaged in worldly actions, and tamas leads to degradation.

19.original_verse: When the one who observes perceives an agent which is not separate from the gunas, and knows the element higher than the gunas, that one reaches my being.
19.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: Realizing the gunas as the cause of actions and transcending them through wisdom leads one to unity with Krishna.

20.original_verse: When the embodied one transcends these three gunas which come into being in the body, that one reaches eternity, and is free from sorrow, old age, death and birth.
20.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: By rising above the gunas, one attains liberation, transcending the cycles of birth and death and achieving eternal freedom.

21.original_verse: Splendid One, does one who has transcended the three gunas have special marks and practice? And how does one transcend the three gunas?
21.speaker: Arjuna

commentary.shankaracharya: Arjuna seeks clarity on the characteristics and methods of transcending the gunas, aiming to understand the liberated state.

22.original_verse: Son of Pandu, that one does not hate occurrences of confusion, or of exertion, or of brightness; nor does that one desire that they not occur.
22.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: A person transcending the gunas neither resents nor craves their effects, maintaining equanimity regardless of circumstances.

23.original_verse: One who stands firm, and does not stir, one who is seated as if sitting apart, who is not shaken by the gunas, but thinks ‘The gunas are turning’.
23.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: The observer remains detached, recognizing the gunas as the forces acting, while staying rooted in their own nature.

24.original_verse: One who is self-contained; for whom pleasure and pain are the same, as are a lump of earth, a stone and a piece of gold; one who is steady, for whom the loved and unloved are equal, as are praise and blame.
24.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: The transcendent individual views dualities such as pleasure and pain, or praise and blame, with the same calm detachment.

25.original_verse: The one for whom honour and dishonour are equal; as are friend and enemy; who abandons all endeavours; that one is said to transcend the gunas.
25.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: Transcendence is marked by impartiality toward relationships and freedom from the pursuit of external objectives.

26.original_verse: And the one who serves me with the yoga of devotion, and does not waver, that one transcends the gunas and becomes ready for becoming one with Brahman.
26.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: Devotion to Krishna, through unwavering focus and practice, leads to transcending the gunas and merging with Brahman.

27.original_verse: I am the support of Brahman, the immortal and imperishable; and the support of everlasting dharma; and the support of unique joy.
27.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: Krishna declares Himself as the foundation of Brahman, eternal righteousness, and supreme bliss, highlighting His transcendental nature.

1.original_verse: They say the ashvattha tree is imperishable, its roots high, its branches below. The metres are its leaves; the one who knows this is wise in the Veda.
1.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: The ashvattha tree symbolizes the impermanence of the material world. Its roots represent Brahman, and its leaves (the Vedas) provide guidance on understanding its essence.

2.original_verse: Its branches spread wide below and above, grown large through the gunas, it sprouts the objects of sense; its roots are stretched below, growing action in the human realm.
2.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: The tree's branches represent the manifestations of the gunas, while its roots symbolize actions that entangle beings in the material world.

3.original_verse: The form of the ashvattha is not to be discerned here, neither its end, nor beginning, nor ongoing life. When its fully grown roots are cut by the strong axe of non-clinging,
3.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: The tree's form is elusive, emphasizing the illusory nature of the world. Detachment is the axe that cuts through this illusion.
