4.original_verse: then that place must be sought where, once they have gone, they will not turn back again, and they think, ‘I take refuge in that first spirit where activity flowed forth in ancient times.’
4.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: Liberation comes from seeking refuge in the eternal source of creation, transcending the cycle of rebirth.

5.original_verse: Without pride or confusion, the wrongs of clinging vanquished, eternal in the highest self, desires turned away, freed from dualities of pleasure and pain, those who are not confused go to that imperishable place.
5.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: Freedom from ego and attachment leads to transcendence, where one attains the imperishable state beyond dualities.

6.original_verse: Neither the sun nor the rabbit-marked moon nor flame lights up that place; when they have gone to my highest dwelling place, they do not return.
6.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: The supreme abode is self-illuminating and eternal, free from the cycles of return.

7.original_verse: Just a fragment of me in the realm of the living is the eternal individual life; it draws to itself the senses dwelling in material nature, and the sixth [sense] is the mind.
7.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: The individual soul, as a fragment of Krishna, interacts with the material world through the senses and mind.

8.original_verse: When the lord gains a body, and when he leaves it, he goes and takes up the senses, just as the wind takes fragrances from the place where they began.
8.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: The soul carries its sensory faculties from one body to another, like wind transporting scents.

9.original_verse: This lord rules taste and smell, hearing, sight and touch, as well as the mind; he enjoys the objects of the senses.
9.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: The individual soul experiences the material world through sensory perceptions, driven by desires.

10.original_verse: The confused do not perceive the lord as he leaves or stays, or partakes in the midst of the gunas, but the ones with eyes of wisdom see him.
10.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: Only the wise perceive the Self as it transcends the gunas and its interactions with the material world.

11.original_verse: In their effort, the practitioners of yoga see this one abiding in the self, but even with effort those thoughtless ones whose selves are not prepared, do not see him.
11.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: Yoga practitioners with disciplined minds perceive the Self, whereas those lacking preparation remain blind to it.

12.original_verse: The brilliance which comes from the sun lights up the world with no break; it is in the moon, and in fire; recognize that brilliance as mine.
12.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: The light of the sun, moon, and fire is an expression of Krishna’s divine brilliance.

13.original_verse: When I enter the earth on which all creatures walk, I preserve all beings with energy. When I become Soma, liquid in nature, I cause the plants to flower.
13.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: Krishna sustains life on Earth through His energy, nurturing all living beings and promoting growth.

14.original_verse: When I become that fire which belongs to all people, and enter the body of all who breathe, I have joined the in-breath with the out-breath, and I cook four kinds of food.
14.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: Krishna, as the digestive fire, processes sustenance within all beings, supporting life’s vital functions.

15.original_verse: I am seated in the heart of all; memory, wisdom and reason come from me. I am especially to be known through the Vedas, as I am a knower of Veda and the creator of Vedanta.
15.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: Krishna resides in every heart as the source of memory, wisdom, and understanding, and is the ultimate knowledge in the Vedas.

16.original_verse: In the world, there are two spirits; one can be destroyed, and the other can never be destroyed. All beings can be destroyed, but the one who stands above all is called the indestructible.
16.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: Krishna distinguishes between the perishable beings of the world and the indestructible Self that transcends material existence.

17.original_verse: But the highest spirit is other than this; it is called the highest self, and when it enters the three worlds, it holds them up as the imperishable lord.
17.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: The supreme Self, beyond both the perishable and indestructible, sustains the entire creation as the imperishable lord.

18.original_verse: Since I go beyond that which is destroyed and am higher even than the indestructible, I am known as the highest self – in the world and in the Veda.
18.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: Krishna asserts His transcendence over all beings, including the indestructible Self, affirming His identity as the supreme reality recognized in the Vedas.

19.original_verse: Son of Bharata, the one who is not confused recognizes me as the highest spirit; recognizing all, that one is devoted to me with fullness of being.
19.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: True wisdom lies in perceiving Krishna as the highest spirit and devoting oneself entirely to Him with clarity and understanding.

20.original_verse: Blameless One, Son of Bharata, this most secret rule is told by me, and when one has awakened, one would be filled with insight, and finished with one’s task.
20.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: Krishna concludes by revealing that understanding this secret teaching leads to enlightenment and the ultimate fulfillment of life's purpose.

1.original_verse: Purity in truth; being without fear; abiding in the yoga of wisdom; sacrifice, self-control and charity; the right path, heated discipline and study of the Vedas;
1.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: Krishna outlines the qualities of the divine, emphasizing fearlessness, inner purity, and steadfastness in spiritual discipline and selfless action.

2.original_verse: absence of harm; truthfulness; absence of anger; renunciation and peace; avoidance of slander; compassion for beings; freedom from lust, kindness, modesty and discretion;
2.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: These traits embody non-violence, honesty, and control over one's emotions, marking divine behavior.

3.original_verse: Son of Bharata, energy, patience, courage and purity; absence of hatred; moderation in honour: these are the traits of those born to the divine condition.
3.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: Divine individuals exhibit endurance, courage, and an absence of hatred, focusing on inner purity and humility.

4.original_verse: Son of Pritha, fraud, insolence and hostile conceit; anger, rough speech too, and ignorance; these are the traits of those born to the demonic condition.
4.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: Krishna contrasts divine traits with demonic ones, emphasizing deceit, arrogance, and ignorance as characteristics to be avoided.

5.original_verse: The divine condition leads to freedom, and the demonic condition leads to bondage. Do not be sorrowful; you are born to the divine condition, Son of Pandu.
5.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: Krishna reassures Arjuna of his divine nature, which leads to liberation, unlike the bondage caused by demonic traits.

6.original_verse: In this realm, there are created two kinds of beings: divine and demonic. The divine has been told in detail; now hear from me about the demonic, Son of Pritha.
6.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: Krishna introduces a deeper explanation of the demonic nature to highlight what should be avoided.

7.original_verse: Demonic men recognize neither exertion, nor its cessation, neither purity nor even good action. There is no truth found in them.
7.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: Demonic individuals lack discernment and truthfulness, ignoring purity and righteous action.

8.original_verse: They do not have truth, and have no place to stand. They say that the earth is godless, not created in causal succession. How else is it caused? They say: ‘It is caused by desire!’
8.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: Demonic perspectives deny divine causation, attributing creation solely to desire, rejecting spiritual foundations.

9.original_verse: Supporting this view, those whose selves are lost, whose insight is narrow and whose actions are cruel come into being as enemies bent on the destruction of the world.
9.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: Those blinded by ignorance and cruelty become adversaries of the world, leading to chaos and destruction.

10.original_verse: Dependent on desire which is hard to satisfy, steeped in fraud, pride and drunkenness, they have grasped false ideas through confusion, and move ahead with impure vows.
10.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: Demonic individuals are driven by insatiable desires, false beliefs, and impure intentions, causing harm to themselves and others.

11.original_verse: With no end of anxious thoughts, clinging to an end which is dissolution, their highest goal is the enjoyment of desire. Without a doubt of [their] truth,
11.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: Driven by endless worries and desires, they remain trapped in the pursuit of transient pleasures.

12.original_verse: they are bound by a hundred snares of hope; their highest goals are anger and desire; they seek hoards of wealth in mistaken ways, for the enjoyment of desire.
12.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: Bound by false hopes, demonic individuals are consumed by anger, greed, and unethical pursuit of wealth.

13.original_verse: ‘This has been gained by me today! And I will get this desire – a desire which carries the mind like a chariot. This wealth is also mine, and so will this be mine!
13.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: Their minds are ensnared by greed and a sense of ownership, constantly chasing material gains.

14.original_verse: This enemy has been struck down by me, and I will strike others too! I am the lord, the one who enjoys, fulfilled, strong and happy.
14.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: Demonic pride manifests in dominance over others, coupled with self-centered joy and arrogance.

15.original_verse: I am rich and well born; who else is there like me? I will sacrifice; I will give; I will be joyful!’ Thus say those confused by ignorance.
15.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: Confusion by ignorance leads to self-conceit and false notions of superiority and generosity.

16.original_verse: Wandering away with many thoughts, they are covered by a net of confusion. Clinging to the enjoyment of desire, they fall into an impure hell.
16.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: The demonic individuals, consumed by endless desires and confusion, are entrapped in a cycle of ignorance and ultimately fall into spiritual degradation.

17.original_verse: Immovable, self-absorbed, accompanied by lust, pride and wealth, they sacrifice in name only, fraudulently, and without Vedic rules.
17.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: Their sacrifices lack sincerity and adhere to no Vedic principles, driven by ego, lust, and the desire for recognition.

18.original_verse: They cling to anger and desire, arrogance and force, and ‘I’-making; those who grumble in this way hate me, whether in their own or another’s body.
18.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: Such individuals are consumed by selfishness and hatred, failing to recognize Krishna's presence within themselves and others.

19.original_verse: In cycles of rebirth, over and over, I throw the impure, wretched people, cruel and filled with hate, into the wombs of demons.
19.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: Those entrenched in demonic traits are condemned to repeated births in inferior states, perpetuating their suffering.

20.original_verse: Son of Kunti, when they have entered the demon womb, they are deluded birth after birth. They do not reach me, and then they travel on the lowest way.
20.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: Demonic tendencies lead to delusion and spiritual ignorance, preventing individuals from attaining liberation or Krishna's grace.

21.original_verse: This is the threefold gate of hell, which destroys the self. Therefore, one should let go the threefold group of greed, anger and desire.
21.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: Krishna warns against greed, anger, and desire, describing them as gateways to spiritual ruin and urging their abandonment.

22.original_verse: Son of Kunti, when one is freed from the three gates of dark tamas, one proceeds in the best way for the self. Thus one goes on the highest way.
22.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: Liberation from tamas and its associated vices allows one to walk the path of righteousness and self-realization.

23.original_verse: The one who lets go of the rule of Vedic law and exists according to his own desires, reaches neither fulfilment nor happiness nor the highest way.
23.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: Ignoring the Vedic principles leads to spiritual stagnation, unfulfilled desires, and failure to attain liberation.

24.original_verse: Thus, following Vedic law, which focuses on that to be done and not to be done, and knowing Vedic law, you should perform action here in this world.
24.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: Krishna emphasizes the importance of aligning actions with Vedic teachings, which guide one toward righteousness and liberation.

1.original_verse: Krishna, what is the place of those who let go of the rule of Vedic law, but who sacrifice filled with trust? Is it sattva, or rajas or tamas?
1.speaker: Arjuna

commentary.shankaracharya: Arjuna asks Krishna about the nature of those who worship with faith but do not follow scriptural injunctions, seeking clarity on their classification among the gunas.

2.original_verse: There are three kinds of trust; it is born of one’s own nature. Listen to this: it can be sattvic, or rajasic, or tamasic.
2.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: Faith varies based on an individual's inherent nature, aligning with the qualities of sattva, rajas, or tamas.

3.original_verse: Son of Bharata, trust follows the truth of each guna. Humans are made of trust; they grow to become whatever they trust.
3.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: A person's faith shapes their essence and actions, influenced by the predominant guna in their nature.

4.original_verse: The sattvic people sacrifice to gods, and the rajasic ones to demons and yakshas. The others, the tamasic ones, sacrifice to the dead and gangs of ghosts.
4.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: Sacrificial preferences vary based on the gunas: sattvic individuals worship gods, rajasic ones revere power-oriented beings, and tamasic ones are drawn to dark entities.

5.original_verse: People who undergo fierce, heated disciplines, not ordained by Vedic law, joined to ‘I’-making and fraud, together with force, rage and desire –
5.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: Krishna criticizes extreme practices driven by ego, desire, and pride that lack scriptural backing and cause harm.

6.original_verse: recognize these as demonic in intent, thoughtlessly harming the multitude of elements in the body, and also harming me, who exists in the body.
6.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: Harmful practices arising from tamas are not only self-destructive but also disrespect the divine essence within all beings.

7.original_verse: Food is also dear to everyone in three ways: as sacrifice, as heat and also as gift. Hear now the difference between them.
7.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: Food preferences are influenced by the gunas and reflect one's nature, impacting health, satisfaction, and spiritual progress.

8.original_verse: The foods that increase satisfaction, pleasure, health, strength, truth and long life, that are flavourful, smooth, firm and pleasant, are dear to the sattvic.
8.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: Sattvic food promotes vitality, clarity, and longevity, aligning with spiritual well-being and harmony.

9.original_verse: Foods that are hot, salty and sour, sharp, burning, rough and fiery, are desired by the rajasic, yielding disease, grief and sorrow.
9.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: Rajasic food stimulates excessive energy but often leads to physical and emotional imbalance.

10.original_verse: Food that is dear to the tamasic is not fit for sacrifice; it is a leftover, and stale, stinking, tasteless and spoiled.
10.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: Tamasic food depletes vitality and clarity, contributing to ignorance and lethargy.

11.original_verse: Sacrifice is sattvic when offered according to Vedic law by those who desire no fruit, and who focus the mind on that which is to be sacrificed.
11.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: Sattvic sacrifice is selfless, adhering to scriptural guidance and performed with devotion and detachment.

12.original_verse: But recognize that sacrifice is rajasic when it is offered with the fruit held in mind, and also offered toward a fraudulent end, Best of the Bharatas.
12.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: Rajasic sacrifices are driven by personal gain or recognition, lacking the purity of intent found in sattvic acts.

13.original_verse: People see as tamasic a sacrifice given without confidence, without sponsorship, the mantras thrown away, the food not offered and Vedic law disparaged.
13.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: Tamasic sacrifices are devoid of faith and respect for tradition, performed carelessly and without proper ritual.

14.original_verse: Honouring the gods, twice-born teachers and people of wisdom; purity, virtue, chastity and absence of harm, are said to be the heated discipline of the body.
14.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: Discipline of the body includes respect for the divine, purity, and adherence to virtuous conduct.

15.original_verse: Speech that does not cause distress, that is truthful, pleasant and beneficial, and the practice of Vedic study, are said to be the heated discipline of the word.
15.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: Discipline of speech emphasizes truthfulness, kindness, and the pursuit of spiritual wisdom through study.

16.original_verse: Clarity of mind, gentleness, self-control, silence and purity of being are said to be the heated discipline of the mind.
16.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: Mental discipline involves cultivating clarity, calmness, and inner purity, essential for spiritual growth.

17.original_verse: They regard this threefold heated discipline as sattvic when it is practised with the highest trust by those who are joined to yoga and desire no fruit.
17.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: Sattvic discipline is marked by selflessness, trust, and alignment with yoga, focusing on spiritual goals rather than material rewards.

18.original_verse: That heated discipline is said to be rajasic, wavering and unfixed, when it is done fraudulently, with the purpose of honour, respect and favour.
18.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: Rajasic discipline is driven by ego and desire for recognition, lacking consistency and purity of intent.

19.original_verse: That heated discipline is said to be tamasic when it is done with torment, with self-deluded ideas, or with the purpose of destroying another being.
19.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: Tamasic discipline involves harmful intent, delusion, and self-inflicted suffering, deviating from spiritual principles.

20.original_verse: That gift given to one who has not done a previous favour, and only with the thought ‘This is to be given’, in the right time and place, and to the right person, that gift is known as sattvic.
20.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: Sattvic giving is selfless, thoughtful, and aligns with dharma, focusing on the act rather than expecting a return.

21.original_verse: But that given with the purpose of reward, or with regard to the fruit, and that given unwillingly, that gift is known as rajasic.
21.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: Rajasic giving is transactional, motivated by selfishness or expectation of a return, and lacks sincerity.

22.original_verse: And that gift given at the wrong place and time, and to the wrong person, without the proper decorum of ritual, and with disrespect, that gift is said to be tamasic.
22.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: Tamasic giving is careless, inappropriate, and performed without respect or understanding of dharma.

23.original_verse: Thus, the Om tat sat is known as the threefold designation of Brahman. In ancient times, the brahmins, the sacrifices and the Vedas were arranged in this way.
23.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: The threefold designation 'Om tat sat' represents Brahman and serves as a guiding principle for sacrifices and Vedic practices.

24.original_verse: When sacrifice, gifts and acts of heated discipline are begun, then ‘Om’ is uttered by those who speak of Brahman, as is told by Vedic law.
24.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: The utterance of 'Om' sanctifies actions like sacrifice and giving, connecting them to Brahman and Vedic tradition.

25.original_verse: Saying ‘tat’ without interest in their fruits, acts of heated discipline, and sacrifice, and different acts of giving, are performed by those who desire freedom.
25.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: The utterance of 'tat' signifies detachment from material results, aligning actions with the pursuit of liberation.

26.original_verse: ‘Sat’ is said in its meaning of true reality and real goodness; thus the word ‘sat’ is also used for a worthy act, Son of Pritha.
26.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: The term 'sat' represents truth and virtue, symbolizing actions that are rooted in righteousness and goodness.

27.original_verse: In sacrifice, in heated discipline and in giving, sat is also called ‘being steadfast’, and action which has this end is also shown to be sat.
27.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: Steadfastness in righteous actions such as giving and discipline is aligned with the principle of 'sat' and reflects spiritual commitment.

28.original_verse: Oblation given, or heated discipline undertaken without trust, is called asat. That is not for us – neither here, nor after death, Son of Pritha.
28.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: Actions performed without faith or sincerity are considered 'asat,' leading to no spiritual benefit in this life or the next.

1.original_verse: O mighty-armed Hrishikesha, I want to know severally the truth about sannyasa as also about tyaga.
1.speaker: Arjuna

commentary.shankaracharya: Arjuna inquires about the difference between renunciation of actions (sannyasa) and the renunciation of the fruits of actions (tyaga), desiring a clear distinction.

2.original_verse: The learned ones know sannyasa to be the giving up of actions done with a desire for reward. The adepts call the abandonment of the results of all works as tyaga.
2.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: Sannyasa is the renunciation of desire-motivated actions, while tyaga refers to abandoning attachment to the results of actions.

3.original_verse: Some learned persons say that action, beset with evil, should be given up, and others say that the practice of sacrifice, charity, and austerity should not be given up.
3.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: There are differing views on renunciation: some advocate abandoning all actions due to their binding nature, while others uphold the value of certain practices for purification.

4.original_verse: O the most excellent among the descendants of Bharata, hear from me the firm conclusion regarding that tyaga. For tyaga has been clearly declared to be of three kinds.
4.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: Krishna emphasizes that renunciation (tyaga) is of three types and is essential for spiritual clarity.

5.original_verse: The practice of sacrifice, charity, and austerity is not to be abandoned; it is surely to be undertaken. Sacrifice, charity, and austerity are verily the purifiers of the wise.
5.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: Krishna highlights the importance of continuing acts of sacrifice, charity, and austerity as they purify the mind and lead to wisdom.

6.original_verse: But even these actions have to be undertaken by renouncing attachment and (hankering for) results. This is my firm and best conclusion, O Partha.
6.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: Actions should be performed selflessly, without attachment to their fruits, aligning with sattvic renunciation.

7.original_verse: The abandoning of daily obligatory acts is not justifiable. Giving up that through delusion is declared to be based on tamas.
7.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: Renouncing obligatory duties out of ignorance or delusion is tamasic and does not lead to spiritual growth.

8.original_verse: Whatever action one may relinquish merely as being painful, from fear of physical suffering, he, having resorted to renunciation based on rajas, will surely not acquire the fruits of renunciation.
8.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: Rajasic renunciation arises from avoidance of discomfort or pain, lacking the purity of intent required for true liberation.

9.original_verse: Whatever obligatory duty is performed just because it is a bounden duty, by giving up attachment and the result as well, that renunciation is considered to be based on sattva.
9.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: Sattvic renunciation entails performing duties selflessly and without seeking personal gain.

10.original_verse: The man of renunciation who has become imbued with sattva, who is wise and freed from doubts, does not hate unbefitting action, nor does he become attached to befitting activity.
10.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: A true renunciate transcends likes and dislikes, acting wisely without attachment or aversion.

11.original_verse: Since it is not possible for one who holds on to a body to give up actions entirely, therefore he, on the other hand, who renounces results of actions is called a man of renunciation.
11.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: Complete renunciation of actions is impractical, but abandoning attachment to results defines true renunciation.

12.original_verse: The threefold results of actions—the undesirable, the desirable, and the mixed—accrues after death to those who do not resort to renunciation, but never to those who resort to monasticism.
12.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: Actions bear results based on intent and attachment; true renunciates transcend these outcomes.

13.original_verse: O mighty-armed one, learn from me these five factors for the accomplishment of all actions, which have been spoken of in Vedanta.
13.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: Krishna introduces the five factors essential for understanding the mechanics of action and their spiritual implications.

14.original_verse: The locus as also the agent, the different kinds of organs, the many and distinct activities, and, the divine is here the fifth.
14.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: The five factors include the body, the doer, the senses, actions, and divine will as the basis of all activities.

15.original_verse: Whatever action a man performs with the body, speech and mind, be it just or its reverse, of it these five are the causes.
15.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: Actions performed through body, speech, or mind are driven by these five interconnected causes.

16.original_verse: This being true, the one who sees his own self as the only agent is hard-headed, and does not see, because of insight which is incomplete.
16.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: Krishna critiques the delusion of egoism, where one sees themselves as the sole doer, ignoring the interconnectedness of all factors in action.

17.original_verse: The one who has no sense of ‘mine’ and whose insight is not stained, that one is not bound and does not kill, even when he kills these very people.
17.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: A person free from attachment and ego acts without incurring bondage, as their actions are aligned with divine will and dharma.

18.original_verse: The three kinds of impulses for action are the wisdom of knowledge, the knower and that which is to be known. The three factors of action are the agent, the act and the means.
18.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: Action arises from the triad of knowledge, the knower, and the object of knowledge, along with the actor, the deed, and its instruments.

19.original_verse: In accounting for the gunas, it is told that wisdom of knowledge, action and means are also threefold, distinguished by gunas. Listen properly to these, also.
19.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: The gunas influence all aspects of action, including knowledge, deeds, and methods, and Krishna explains their distinctions.

20.original_verse: That wisdom of knowledge by which one sees the imperishable in all beings, and the whole in multiplicities – recognize that wisdom as sattvic.
20.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: Sattvic knowledge perceives unity in diversity, recognizing the eternal presence of Brahman in all beings.

21.original_verse: But that wisdom which understands different natures of different kinds, each separate in all beings – recognize that wisdom as rajasic.
21.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: Rajasic knowledge perceives distinctions and separateness among beings, focusing on dualities and differences.

22.original_verse: But that which clings to only one action to be done without motive, trifling and without true aim – that is said to be tamasic.
22.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: Tamasic knowledge is narrow, lacking purpose and insight, leading to ignorance and stagnation.

23.original_verse: That action which is free from clinging and restrained, performed without hatred or desire, without longing to acquire the fruit, that action is said to be sattvic.
23.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: Sattvic action is selfless, disciplined, and motivated by duty rather than personal gain or aversion.

24.original_verse: But that action performed with longing to acquire, with a strong sense of ‘I’, or further, with much striving, is said to be rajasic.
24.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: Rajasic actions are driven by ego and ambition, often resulting in overexertion and attachment to outcomes.

25.original_verse: That action begun because of delusion, without heeding the consequences, or the effects of power, or loss, or injury, is said to be tamasic.
25.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: Tamasic actions are reckless and unwise, performed without consideration of consequences or dharma.

26.original_verse: The actor who is free from clinging and talk of self, who is accompanied by effort and courage, unchanged by fulfilment or lack of fulfilment, is said to be sattvic.
26.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: Sattvic individuals act with determination, courage, and detachment from success or failure.

27.original_verse: The passionate actor longing to acquire the fruit of action, impure, greedy, whose nature is violent and filled with pain and pleasure, is said to be rajasic.
27.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: Rajasic actors are dominated by desires and emotional extremes, leading to unrest and impurity.

28.original_verse: The actor who is stubborn and vulgar, not joined to yoga, lazy, false and wicked, despondent and procrastinating, is said to be tamasic.
28.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: Tamasic individuals are characterized by laziness, deceit, and a lack of discipline, resulting in spiritual stagnation.

29.original_verse: Arjuna, Winner of Wealth, now hear the three kinds of insight and courage, according to the gunas, set forth completely, one by one.
29.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: Krishna introduces the threefold classification of insight and courage, explaining their alignment with the gunas.

30.original_verse: Son of Pritha, that insight which distinguishes exertion from inertia; that to be done from that not to be done; that to be feared from that not to be feared, is sattvic.
30.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: Sattvic insight is discerning and clear, enabling one to make wise decisions aligned with dharma.

31.original_verse: And, Son of Pritha, the insight which does not distinguish correctly between dharma and its absence, between that to be done and that not to be done, is rajasic.
31.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: Rajasic insight is clouded by partiality and ambition, leading to misjudgment in discerning right from wrong.

32.original_verse: Son of Pritha, the insight wrapped in darkness which thinks that all things are backwards, and that the dharma is its absence, is tamasic.
32.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: Tamasic insight is deluded, confusing righteousness with its opposite, resulting in moral and spiritual darkness.

33.original_verse: Son of Pritha, by yoga which does not stray, the steadiness with which one maintains the actions of the senses, the vital breath and the mind, that steadiness is sattvic.
33.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: Sattvic steadiness arises from unwavering focus and self-control, aligning actions with spiritual discipline.

34.original_verse: But Arjuna, Son of Pritha, the steadiness with which one maintains wealth, desire and dharma, longing for the fruit with clinging, that steadiness is rajasic.
34.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: Rajasic steadiness is driven by attachment to material gains, ambition, and the desire for recognition.

35.original_verse: Son of Pritha, the steadiness with which a dull-witted one holds on to pride and despondence, or pain, fear and sleep, that steadiness is tamasic.
35.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: Tamasic steadiness stems from ignorance, leading to inaction, fear, and procrastination.

36.original_verse: But now, hear from me, Bull of the Bharatas, the three grades of joy which one can experience through practice, and arrive at an end of sorrow:
36.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: Krishna introduces the three types of joy classified by the gunas, emphasizing their effects on spiritual progress.

37.original_verse: That joy which is like poison in the beginning, and is like nectar when transformed, born from clarity in the insight of the self, is said to be sattvic;
37.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: Sattvic joy arises from spiritual discipline, initially challenging but ultimately rewarding and liberating.

38.original_verse: That joy which is like nectar in the beginning, and poison when transformed through contact between the senses and their objects, is known as rajasic;
38.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: Rajasic joy stems from sensory pleasures, initially enticing but eventually leading to dissatisfaction and bondage.

39.original_verse: And that joy which in its beginning and in its end deludes the self, and arises from confusion, laziness and sleep, is said to be tamasic.
39.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: Tamasic joy is rooted in ignorance and apathy, offering neither immediate nor lasting fulfillment.

40.original_verse: There is no being on earth, or in heaven, or among the gods – no being who is free from these three gunas born of nature.
40.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: Krishna asserts that all beings are influenced by the gunas, which govern their nature and actions.

41.original_verse: Scorcher of the Enemy, the actions of brahmin priests, kshatriya warriors and vaishya merchants are portioned out by the gunas, sources of each innate nature.
41.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: Each caste's duties arise naturally from their dominant guna, shaping their roles in society and dharma.

42.original_verse: Brahmin action is born from the nature within: calmness, restraint, heated discipline, purity, patience, honesty, wisdom, discernment and a sense of presence.
42.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: The qualities of a Brahmin align with sattva, emphasizing wisdom, self-control, and purity as essential for spiritual guidance.

43.original_verse: Warrior action is born from the nature within: might, inner light, courage and skill, and not fleeing in battle, generosity and a lordly temperament.
43.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: Kshatriyas embody rajas, characterized by strength, bravery, and leadership in fulfilling their duty to protect and govern.

44.original_verse: Vaishya merchant action is born from the nature within: trade, cow-herding and ploughing; and the action of service is born from the nature within of shudras, those who serve.
44.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: Vaishyas and Shudras contribute through commerce and service, each role aligned with their dominant guna.

45.original_verse: Content in one’s own action, one gains complete fulfilment. Hear then how one who is content in his own action finds fulfilment:
45.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: Performing one's dharma with contentment leads to self-fulfillment and spiritual progress.

46.original_verse: Honouring by one’s own action the one from whom all beings come forth, the one by whom all the world is pervaded, a human being finds fulfilment.
46.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: Performing one’s natural duties with devotion to the all-pervading divine source leads to ultimate fulfillment.

47.original_verse: One’s own dharma, however badly done, is a higher good than another’s dharma, however well done; if one performs action as set down by one’s own nature, one does not create fault.
47.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: It is better to follow one’s natural path, even imperfectly, than to excel in another’s duties, as one’s own dharma aligns with inherent nature.

48.original_verse: Son of Kunti, one should not let go of one’s natural action, even if it is flawed. All beginnings are surrounded by error, as fire is surrounded by smoke.
48.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: Flaws in natural actions are unavoidable, much like smoke accompanies fire; perseverance is key to progress.

49.original_verse: With insight that clings to nothing, with longing passed away, one’s self subdued, through renunciation one goes to the highest fulfilment in the state beyond action.
49.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: Renouncing attachment and desires leads to liberation, transcending the cycle of action and its consequences.

50.original_verse: Son of Kunti, learn from me briefly: the one who has found fulfilment also gains Brahman, the highest state of wisdom.
50.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: Attaining fulfillment through detachment and self-realization leads to union with Brahman, the ultimate wisdom.

51.original_verse: Joined to pure insight and restraining the self with steadiness, letting go of the objects of sense, starting with sound, throwing aside passion and hatred,
51.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: Self-restraint and detachment from sensory pleasures, combined with clarity and neutrality, purify the mind.

52.original_verse: Consuming lightly, dwelling apart, controlled in body, mind and speech, eternally holding the yoga of meditation as the highest end,
52.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: A disciplined lifestyle of simplicity, solitude, and focused meditation aligns the self with higher spiritual goals.

53.original_verse: Releasing pride, force and the focus on ‘I’ of grasping, anger and desire, at peace and without a sense of ‘mine’, one becomes fit for the being of Brahman.
53.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: Letting go of ego, attachment, and negative emotions prepares the mind for union with Brahman.

54.original_verse: The one whose self is tranquil, of one being with Brahman, who neither grieves nor desires, for whom all beings are the same, gains the highest devotion to me.
54.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: Equanimity and absence of desires foster tranquility, leading to unwavering devotion to Krishna.

55.original_verse: Through devotion to me one comes to know how far I reach; and who I truly am. And then, when one knows me truly, one enters me in an instant.
55.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: True understanding of Krishna’s infinite nature through devotion leads to spiritual union with Him.

56.original_verse: Further, if one is always performing all actions while taking refuge in me, one reaches through my grace an imperishable, unchanging home.
56.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: Surrendering all actions to Krishna ensures His grace, leading to liberation and an eternal abode.

57.original_verse: Renouncing by thought all actions to me, and holding me as the highest, take refuge in the yoga of insight, and think of me always.
57.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: Devotion combined with thoughtful renunciation and constant focus on Krishna leads to spiritual alignment.

58.original_verse: When you think of me, through my grace you will cross into all those places so hard to reach, but if you cannot listen, from a sense of ‘mine’, you will die.
58.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: Krishna assures that His grace overcomes all obstacles, but attachment to ego leads to spiritual failure.

59.original_verse: If you take refuge in the sense of ‘mine’, and think, ‘I will not fight’, your resolve is hopeless, and the force of nature will command you.
59.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: Clinging to ego and avoiding one’s duty is futile, as the force of nature ensures the fulfillment of one’s destiny.

60.original_verse: Son of Kunti, through that which arises out of your own nature, bound by your own action in confusion you will do even that which you do not want to do.
60.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: One’s innate nature and past actions compel them to act in alignment with their dharma, even against their desires.

61.original_verse: Arjuna, the lord of all beings dwells in the place of the heart, and causes all beings to wander in illusion, as if following a great cosmic map.
61.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: Krishna explains that the divine resides within all beings, orchestrating their actions through the power of maya (illusion).

62.original_verse: Son of Bharata, go, with your whole being, to that one refuge, and from that grace you will reach the eternal dwelling place, and the highest peace.
62.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: Seeking refuge in Krishna with total surrender leads to liberation and eternal peace.

63.original_verse: So this wisdom told to you by me is more hidden than the hidden; and when you have pondered this completely, then do as you like.
63.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: Krishna emphasizes that this teaching is esoteric and encourages Arjuna to reflect deeply before deciding his course of action.

64.original_verse: Even further, listen to my highest word: the most hidden of all; you are greatly loved by me, so I will speak for your benefit.
64.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: Out of divine love for Arjuna, Krishna reveals the most profound and secret knowledge for his ultimate benefit.

65.original_verse: Devoted to me, keep your mind intent on me, give honour to me, and sacrifice to me. In this way, you will truly go to me, I promise, for you are my beloved.
65.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: Complete devotion and surrender to Krishna ensure union with Him, as promised by the divine out of love.

66.original_verse: Letting go of all dharmas, take me alone as your place of rest, and do not grieve, because I will free you from all evils.
66.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: Abandoning all other paths and surrendering solely to Krishna brings freedom from sin and sorrow.

67.original_verse: This should never be spoken by you to one who lacks the heat of discipline, or who is not devoted to me, or who does not want to hear what is to be said, or who sneers at me.
67.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: Krishna advises that this sacred teaching is meant only for those with faith, devotion, and an earnest desire to learn.

68.original_verse: The one who sets forth this highest, hidden truth to those who are devoted to me, and has shown the highest love for me, will without a doubt go to me.
68.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: Sharing this wisdom with devoted individuals demonstrates the highest form of love for Krishna and ensures spiritual union with Him.

69.original_verse: No one among all humankind will give more love to me, and there will be no other on earth dearer to me than that one.
69.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: Krishna expresses unparalleled affection for those who spread His teachings with devotion and sincerity.

70.original_verse: And my thought is this: one who learns and recites this conversation of ours so filled with dharma would sacrifice to me with the sacrifice of knowledge.
70.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: Reciting and understanding the Gita constitutes a supreme offering of knowledge, pleasing to Krishna.

71.original_verse: And also one who would hear without sneering, full of trust, would be freed, and would reach those happy worlds where actions are pure.
71.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: Listening to the Gita with faith and trust leads to liberation and higher spiritual realms.

72.original_verse: Son of Pritha, have you listened to this with focused thought? Have your ignorance and confusion been taken away, Winner of Wealth?
72.speaker: Krishna

commentary.shankaracharya: Krishna asks if Arjuna has truly understood and overcome his doubts through the teachings.

73.original_verse: Unfailing Krishna, through your grace, I have gained wise memory, and lost delusion. I stand here with my doubt gone. I will do what you say.
73.speaker: Arjuna

commentary.shankaracharya: Arjuna acknowledges the transformative power of Krishna's teachings, resolving to follow His guidance.

74.original_verse: Thus, I have heard the conversation between the son of Vasudeva and the son of Pritha, whose nature is great. It was miraculous and caused my hair to stand on end!
74.speaker: Sanjaya

commentary.shankaracharya: Sanjaya marvels at the divine dialogue, recognizing its profound and transformative nature.

75.original_verse: By the grace of Vyasa, the composer, I have heard this highest, hidden yoga from Krishna, lord of yoga, speaking himself, right before my eyes.
75.speaker: Sanjaya

commentary.shankaracharya: Through Vyasa’s grace, Sanjaya witnesses and recounts the profound dialogue, recognizing Krishna as the ultimate teacher of yoga.

76.original_verse: King, remembering continually this miraculous and sacred dialogue between Arjuna and lovely-haired Krishna, I rejoice again and again.
76.speaker: Sanjaya

commentary.shankaracharya: Sanjaya expresses profound joy and gratitude for witnessing the sacred dialogue between Krishna and Arjuna, which is both miraculous and transformative.

77.original_verse: King, remembering again and again the miraculous form of Hari, my wonder is great, and I rejoice again and again.
77.speaker: Sanjaya

commentary.shankaracharya: Reflecting on Krishna’s divine form fills Sanjaya with awe and wonder, inspiring repeated joy and reverence.

78.original_verse: This is my thought: wherever there is Krishna, the lord of yoga, wherever there is Arjuna, Son of Pritha, bearing his bow, there will always be splendour, victory, well-being, and wise conduct.
78.speaker: Sanjaya

commentary.shankaracharya: Sanjaya concludes with confidence that Krishna's guidance and Arjuna's righteous action will ensure success, prosperity, and wisdom.
